skill.name: vet
skill.description: Run vet immediately after ANY logical unit of code changes. Do not batch your changes, do not wait to be asked to run vet, make sure you are proactive.
skill.summary: Run vet immediately after ANY logical unit of code changes. Do not batch your changes, do not wait t...
skill.author: imbue-ai

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate code review tool that analyzes AI assistant session history and git diffs. The static scanner flagged 54 potential issues, but all are false positives. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' alerts are triggered by argparse (command-line parsing), not crypto code. 'Shell backtick' alerts are markdown code blocks showing example commands, not actual execution. 'Hidden file' and 'system reconnaissance' alerts are legitimate file path accesses to session storage required for the tool to function.

high_findings.title: False Positive: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged 'argparse' module as weak crypto. This is a command-line argument parsing library, not a cryptographic module. No cryptographic operations present.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: argparse is a standard Python library for command-line parsing, not cryptography. No hash, cipher, or crypto operations exist in the codebase.

high_findings.title: False Positive: Shell Backtick Execution
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged backticks in markdown as shell execution. These are markdown code blocks showing example commands, not actual code execution.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backticks in SKILL.md are within markdown fenced code blocks (```bash). They are documentation examples, not executable code.

high_findings.title: False Positive: Hidden File Access
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged accessing ~/.claude, ~/.codex as hidden file access. These are required session storage paths for reading AI assistant conversation history.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Accessing session storage at ~/.claude/projects/, ~/.codex/sessions/ is required functionality for the skill to read conversation history for analysis.

low_findings.title: False Positive: System Reconnaissance
low_findings.description: Scanner flagged file system access as system reconnaissance. This is legitimate session storage access required for the tool to function.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Accessing ~/.local/share/opencode/storage/ is required to read session messages. This is intended functionality, not reconnaissance.

content.user_title: Review code with vet after every change
content.value_statement: Vet helps AI coding assistants identify issues in their code changes by analyzing git diffs and conversation history. Run it immediately after any logical unit of code changes to catch misunderstandings between what was requested and what was implemented.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes git diffs to find issues in code changes
Reviews conversation history to catch misunderstandings between user requests and implementation
Works with Claude Code, Codex, and OpenCode session formats
Supports configurable confidence thresholds for findings
Outputs results in text, JSON, or GitHub-compatible formats
Can route analysis through local CLI instead of API for offline use
limitations: Does not replace running tests - it is a complementary review tool
May report issues from other agents or sessions in shared repositories
Requires access to session history files to function with full context
Requires Python with pip or uv to install the vet package

use_cases.title: Catch bugs early in development
use_cases.description: Run vet after each code change to catch bugs before they accumulate. The tool reviews the git diff and conversation context to identify potential issues.
use_cases.target_user: AI coding assistants working on bug fixes

use_cases.title: Improve code quality during feature development
use_cases.description: Use vet to verify implementation matches user intent by analyzing conversation history alongside code changes.
use_cases.target_user: Developers building new features with AI assistants

use_cases.title: Review AI-generated code manually
use_cases.description: Vet provides an additional layer of review for AI-generated code, catching issues that the AI may have missed.
use_cases.target_user: Software developers using AI coding tools

prompt_templates.title: Basic vet check
prompt_templates.prompt: Run vet on the current changes to review the code.
prompt_templates.scenario: Use after making code changes to get immediate feedback

prompt_templates.title: Vet with specific focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Run vet on the current changes focusing on security issues.
prompt_templates.scenario: Target specific aspects like security, performance, or style

prompt_templates.title: Vet with custom model
prompt_templates.prompt: Run vet using the claude-sonnet-4 model with a 0.9 confidence threshold.
prompt_templates.scenario: Use a different model or stricter confidence threshold

prompt_templates.title: Vet with agentic mode
prompt_templates.prompt: Run vet in agentic mode to route through local Claude Code CLI.
prompt_templates.scenario: Use when API keys are not available

output_examples.input: Run vet on the current changes
output_examples.output:
Vet found 2 issues:

1. [HIGH] Unused variable in auth.py:23
   The variable 'token' is assigned but never used.

2. [MEDIUM] Missing error handling in database.py:45
   Database connection errors are not caught.

Recommendation: Review these issues before committing.

best_practices: Run vet immediately after every logical unit of code changes, not in batches
Review issues that relate to changes you actually made, not other agents
Use the --agentic mode when API keys are unavailable but expect slower analysis
anti_patterns: Do not ignore issues without reviewing them - they may indicate real problems
Do not run vet only at the end of a large feature - catch issues early
Do not assume vet replaces testing - it complements but does not replace tests

faq.question: What is vet?
faq.answer: Vet is a code review tool that analyzes git diffs and conversation history to find issues in code changes. It helps AI coding assistants catch bugs and misunderstandings early.

faq.question: How do I install vet?
faq.answer: Install vet using pip with 'pip install verify-everything' or uv with 'uv pip install verify-everything'. Verify installation with 'vet --help'.

faq.question: Does vet replace tests?
faq.answer: No, vet does not replace tests. It is a complementary review tool that catches issues that tests might miss, such as logical misunderstandings.

faq.question: Which AI tools does vet support?
faq.answer: Vet supports Claude Code, Codex, and OpenCode. Each tool has specific session export scripts in the scripts/ directory.

faq.question: Why does vet access session files?
faq.answer: Vet reads conversation history to understand the context of code changes. This helps identify misunderstandings between what was requested and what was implemented.

faq.question: What is agentic mode?
faq.answer: Agentic mode routes vet analysis through the locally installed Claude Code or Codex CLI instead of calling the API directly. Use this when API keys are unavailable. It is slower but works offline.
